Content: This Act may be called the Information Technology Act, 2000. It extends to the whole of India and applies to any offense or contravention committed outside India by any person. It shall come into force on such date as the Central Government may notify. Nothing in this Act shall apply to documents or transactions specified in the First Schedule, but the Central Government may amend the schedule by notification.

1. Access – Gaining entry into, instructing, or communicating with a computer system or network.
2. Addressee – A person intended to receive an electronic record, excluding intermediaries.
3. Adjudicating Officer – An officer appointed under Section 46 to adjudicate cyber law violations.
4. Affixing electronic signature – The act of authenticating an electronic record through a digital signature.

Electronic records can be authenticated using a digital signature, which employs asymmetric cryptography and hash functions. The hash function converts data into a unique hash result, ensuring data integrity and preventing unauthorized modifications. A digital signature, created using a private key, is unique to the signatory and can be verified using their public key. This ensures that the record remains tamper-proof and authentic.

Electronic signatures provide an alternative method of authentication, ensuring security and reliability. They must be uniquely linked to the signatory, controlled by them, and capable of detecting alterations. The government prescribes approved authentication techniques and can modify them as needed. The verification process ensures that the electronic signature belongs to the claimed signatory.

Any law requiring information to be in written, typewritten, or printed form is satisfied if the data is available in an electronic format and can be accessed when needed. This establishes the validity of digital records in legal proceedings and transactions.

Wherever a signature is legally required, an electronic signature can be used instead, provided it follows prescribed security and verification standards. The government ensures that electronic signatures offer the same authenticity and integrity as physical signatures.

Description: Section 6-Use of Electronic Records in Government
Content: Government agencies can process applications, grant licenses, issue approvals, and handle payments electronically. The appropriate government determines the format and security measures required for these electronic transactions, facilitating e-governance.

Description: Section 6A-Delivery of Services by Service Providers
Content: Authorized service providers, including private companies, individuals, and firms, can offer government services electronically. They can collect service charges as prescribed by the government and must comply with operational guidelines to maintain security and efficiency in service delivery.

Laws requiring document retention are fulfilled if electronic records are stored in a way that maintains accessibility, originality, and accuracy. The format must preserve details such as origin, destination, date, and time of transactions, ensuring compliance with record-keeping laws.

Any legal requirement for auditing records extends to electronic records, ensuring they meet standards of transparency, security, and authenticity. Digital audits must verify compliance with data protection and retention policies.

Government regulations, orders, and notifications can be published in an Electronic Gazette, which holds the same legal validity as a physical gazette. This ensures accessibility and transparency of government communications.

Description: Section 9-No Right to Demand Electronic Format
Content: Individuals cannot demand that a government body accept or issue documents electronically unless explicitly allowed by law. This prevents mandatory electronic documentation in cases where physical records are required.

The government defines the type, format, and security standards for electronic signatures, ensuring they are reliable for identity verification. It also prescribes control processes to maintain data security and prevent fraud.

Contracts formed electronically are legally binding, ensuring that digital transactions and agreements hold the same enforceability as traditional contracts. This provision supports e-commerce and online business transactions.

An electronic record is attributed to the originator if it was sent by them, by an authorized person acting on their behalf, or through an automated information system programmed by them. This ensures accountability and authenticity in electronic communication.

An acknowledgment of an electronic record can be given through direct communication, automated responses, or any conduct indicating receipt. If the originator has required an acknowledgment for the record to be binding, failure to receive it renders the record non-binding. If no stipulated method exists and an acknowledgment is not received within a reasonable time, the originator may notify the addressee and consider the record as never sent.

Description: Section 13-Time and Place of Dispatch and Receipt of Electronic Record
Content: Dispatch occurs when the electronic record leaves the originator’s control. Receipt is determined based on whether the addressee has designated a system for receiving electronic records. If no specific system is designated, receipt occurs when the record enters the addressee’s system. The location of dispatch and receipt is deemed to be the business place of the originator and addressee, respectively.
An electronic record is considered secure if a security procedure has been applied to it at a specific point in time, ensuring its integrity and authenticity from that point until verification.

An electronic signature is deemed secure if the signature creation data was under the exclusive control of the signatory at the time of signing and was stored in a secure manner. Digital signatures use private keys as signature creation data.
The Central Government prescribes security procedures for electronic records and signatures, considering commercial needs, transaction nature, and other relevant factors.

Description: Section 17-Appointment of Controller and Other Officers
Content: The Central Government appoints a Controller of Certifying Authorities along with Deputy and Assistant Controllers to oversee digital certification processes. Their qualifications and terms of service are prescribed by the government.

The Controller supervises Certifying Authorities, certifies public keys, sets standards for digital certification, and regulates the business of Certifying Authorities. It also ensures compliance with security protocols and resolves disputes between authorities and subscribers.
The Controller, with government approval, may recognize foreign Certifying Authorities for issuing electronic signatures. Recognition may be revoked if conditions are violated.

Description: Section 21-License to Issue Electronic Signature Certificates
Content: Any person may apply for a license to issue electronic signature certificates, subject to government-prescribed qualifications, expertise, and infrastructure requirements. The license is non-transferable and valid for a specified period.
An application for a Certifying Authority license must include a certification practice statement, applicant identification procedures, prescribed fees, and other required documents.
A Certifying Authority must apply for license renewal at least 45 days before expiration. The application must be submitted in the prescribed form with the required fees.

Description: Section 24-Procedure for Grant or Rejection of License
Content: The Controller assesses license applications based on submitted documents and other relevant factors. If rejected, the applicant is given an opportunity to present their case.

The Controller may suspend a Certifying Authority’s license if they provide false information, violate license terms, or fail to maintain prescribed standards. The Certifying Authority is given an opportunity to respond before revocation.
If a Certifying Authority’s license is suspended or revoked, the Controller publishes a notice in a public database accessible online and through other media if necessary.
The Controller or an authorized officer can investigate any violation of the IT Act using the same powers as Income Tax authorities under the Income-tax Act, 1961.

If a violation is suspected, the Controller or an authorized person may access a computer system, data, or related materials for investigation. They may direct concerned personnel to provide technical assistance.

Description: Section 30-Certifying Authority to Follow Certain Procedures
Content: Certifying Authorities must ensure secure systems, reliable services, privacy of electronic signatures, and adherence to prescribed security procedures.
Certifying Authorities must ensure that all employees comply with IT Act regulations, maintaining proper security and reliability in operations.
Every Certifying Authority shall display its licence at a conspicuous place of the premises in which it carries on its business
If a Certifying Authority’s license is suspended or revoked, they must surrender it immediately. Failure to comply results in penalties, including imprisonment or fines.
Certifying Authorities must disclose electronic signature certificates, certification practice statements, and any information affecting reliability to the public.

Description: Section 35-Certifying Authority to Issue Electronic Signature Certificates
Content: Any person can apply to a Certifying Authority for an electronic signature certificate. The application must be in the prescribed format and accompanied by a fee up to Rs. 25,000. The Certifying Authority reviews the application and either grants or rejects it with written reasons. The applicant has the right to be heard before rejection.

Description: Section 36-Representations upon Issuance of Digital Signature Certificate
Content: A Certifying Authority must ensure compliance with IT Act provisions when issuing a Digital Signature Certificate. It guarantees that the subscriber holds the private key corresponding to the public key, and that the certificate is accurate and publicly available.

A Certifying Authority can suspend a Digital Signature Certificate upon a request from the subscriber or an authorized representative. It can also suspend it in the public interest. However, suspension cannot exceed 15 days without giving the subscriber a chance to be heard.

A Digital Signature Certificate may be revoked upon request by the subscriber, in case of the subscriber's death, or if the subscriber is a dissolved firm or company. Additionally, revocation can occur if the certificate contains false information, the issuing authority's security is compromised, or the subscriber is declared insolvent.
When a Digital Signature Certificate is suspended or revoked, the Certifying Authority must publish a notice in the designated repository to inform all relevant parties.
Subscribers must generate a key pair using a security procedure before accepting a Digital Signature Certificate. This ensures secure authentication in electronic transactions.
A subscriber accepts a Digital Signature Certificate by publishing, authorizing, or approving it. Once accepted, they confirm the accuracy of the information and ownership of the private key.

Subscribers must protect their private key and prevent unauthorized access. If compromised, they must immediately inform the Certifying Authority (CA). Until notified, they remain liable for its misuse.

Description: Section 43-Penalty and Compensation for Damage to Computer Systems
Content: Any unauthorized access, data theft, virus introduction, disruption, or tampering with computer systems is punishable with compensation for damages caused. This protects digital resources from cyber threats and unauthorized activities.

Description: Section 43A-Compensation for Failure to Protect Data
Content: Companies handling sensitive personal data must implement reasonable security practices. If negligence results in wrongful loss or gain, the affected person is entitled to compensation.

Description: Section 44-Penalty for Failure to Furnish Information
Content: Failing to submit required documents, returns, or reports to the Controller or Certifying Authority may result in a penalty of up to Rs. 1,50,000 per failure, with additional daily fines for continued violations.
If no specific penalty is provided for a rule violation under this Act, the offender must pay compensation or a penalty of up to ₹25,000 to the affected person.

The Central Government appoints adjudicating officers to determine IT Act violations. They have civil court powers and can impose penalties or award compensation. Claims above Rs. 5 crores go to a competent court.

Description: Section 47-Factors to be taken into account by the adjudicating officer
Content: The adjudicating officer determines compensation based on unfair gain from the violation,loss caused to the affected person,repetitive nature of the offense.
The Cyber Appellate Tribunal consists of one Chairperson and any other members appointed by the Central Government as deemed necessary.

Description: Section 55-Orders Constituting Cyber Appellate Tribunal Not to be Questioned
Content: The validity of an order constituting the Cyber Appellate Tribunal cannot be questioned in any legal proceedings.
Any person aggrieved by an adjudicating officer's order under this Act may appeal to the Cyber Appellate Tribunal within the prescribed time limit.

Description: Section 58-Procedure and Powers of Cyber Appellate Tribunal
Content: The Cyber Appellate Tribunal follows principles of natural justice, has powers similar to a civil court, and can regulate its own procedure.
A person can appear before the Cyber Appellate Tribunal personally or through a legal practitioner or authorized representative.
The provisions of the Limitation Act, 1963, shall apply to an appeal made to the Appellate Tribunal as far as possible.

No civil court shall have jurisdiction over matters that fall under the authority of the adjudicating officer or the Appellate Tribunal. Courts cannot grant injunctions on actions taken under this Act.

An aggrieved person may file an appeal to the High Court within 60 days from the communication of the Appellate Tribunal's order. The High Court may extend this period by an additional 60 days if justified.
The Controller or adjudicating officer may compound contraventions before or after adjudication, subject to conditions. Compounding is not allowed for repeat offenses within three years.
Unpaid penalties or compensation under this Act shall be recovered as arrears of land revenue, and relevant licenses or electronic signature certificates may be suspended until paid.
Knowingly concealing, destroying, or altering required computer source code is punishable with imprisonment up to three years or a fine up to two lakh rupees, or both.
Dishonestly or fraudulently committing any act listed in Section 43 is punishable with imprisonment up to three years or a fine up to five lakh rupees, or both.

Description: Section 66A-Sending Offensive Messages Through Communication Services
Content: Sending offensive, menacing, false, or misleading electronic messages with intent to annoy, deceive, or harm is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and a fine.

Description: Section 66B-Dishonest Receipt of Stolen Computer Resource or Device
Content: Knowingly receiving or retaining a stolen computer resource or communication device is punishable with imprisonment up to three years or a fine up to one lakh rupees, or both.
Fraudulently or dishonestly using another person's electronic signature, password, or unique identification is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and a fine up to one lakh rupees.

Description: Section 66D-Cheating by Personation Using Computer Resource
Content: Cheating by personation through a computer resource is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and a fine up to one lakh rupees.
Capturing, publishing, or transmitting private images of a person without consent is punishable with imprisonment up to three years or a fine up to two lakh rupees, or both.
Acts that threaten national security, cause harm, or disrupt essential services via computer resources constitute cyber terrorism, punishable with life imprisonment.

Description: Section 67-Publishing or Transmitting Obscene Material in Electronic Form
Content: Publishing or transmitting obscene material electronically is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and a fine up to five lakh rupees for the first offense. Subsequent offenses attract higher penalties.

Description: Section 67A-Publishing or Transmitting Sexually Explicit Material
Content: Publishing or transmitting sexually explicit content electronically is punishable with imprisonment up to five years and a fine up to ten lakh rupees. Repeat offenses lead to stricter penalties.
Publishing, transmitting, or possessing child sexual abuse material (CSAM) in electronic form is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years and a fine up to ten lakh rupees.

Description: Section 67C-Preservation and retention of information by intermediaries
Content: Intermediary shall preserve and retain such information as may be specified for such duration and in such manner and format as the Central Government may prescribe. Any intermediary who intentionally or knowingly contravenes the provisions shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and also be liable to fine.

Description: Section 68-Power of Controller to give directions
Content: The Controller may direct a Certifying Authority or any employee to take measures to ensure compliance with the Act. Failure to comply with such orders may result in imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or a fine not exceeding one lakh rupees or both.

Description: Section 69-Power to issue directions for interception or monitoring or decryption of information
Content: The Government may order interception, monitoring, or decryption of any information for reasons such as sovereignty, integrity, defense, or public order. Failure to comply results in imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine.

Description: Section 69A-Power to issue directions for blocking public access to information
Content: The Government may direct blocking of public access to information if necessary for sovereignty, security, or public order. Non-compliance leads to imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine.

Description: Section 69B-Power to monitor and collect traffic data for cybersecurity
Content: The Government may authorize monitoring and collection of traffic data to enhance cybersecurity. Non-compliance results in imprisonment for up to three years and a fine.
Critical Information Infrastructure may be declared as a protected system. Unauthorized access to such a system is punishable with imprisonment up to ten years and a fine.

Description: Section70A-National nodal agency for Critical Information Infrastructure Protection
Content: The Government may designate an organization as the national nodal agency responsible for protecting Critical Information Infrastructure.

CERT-In is the national agency for cybersecurity incident response. It may issue guidelines and call for information. Failure to comply may result in imprisonment for up to one year or a fine up to one lakh rupees or both.
Misrepresentation to obtain an electronic signature certificate is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or a fine up to one lakh rupees or both.

Description: Section 72-Penalty for breach of confidentiality and privacy
Content: Unauthorized disclosure of electronic records without consent is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or a fine up to one lakh rupees or both.

Description: Section 72A-Punishment for disclosure of information in breach of lawful contract
Content: Disclosure of personal information in breach of contract is punishable with imprisonment up to three years or a fine up to five lakh rupees or both.

Description: Section 73-Penalty for publishing false electronic signature certificate
Content: Publishing a false electronic signature certificate knowingly is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or a fine up to one lakh rupees or both.
Creating or publishing a fraudulent electronic signature certificate is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or a fine up to one lakh rupees or both.

Description: Section 75-Act to apply for offences committed outside India
Content: The IT Act applies to offences committed outside India if the act involves a computer or network located in India.
Any computer or accessory used in contravention of the Act may be confiscated unless the owner proves non-involvement.
Certain offences under the Act may be settled by a court except those affecting socio-economic conditions or committed against children or women.
Offences with imprisonment of three years are bailable, whereas those exceeding three years are cognizable.
A police officer not below the rank of Inspector shall investigate offences under this Act.

Description: Section79-Exemption from liability of intermediary in certain cases
Content: An intermediary shall not be liable for any third-party information, data, or communication link made available or hosted by them, provided they comply with due diligence and government guidelines. However, this exemption does not apply if the intermediary aids or abets unlawful acts or fails to act on government notifications regarding illegal content.

Description: Section 79A-Central Government to notify Examiner of Electronic Evidence
Content: The Central Government may designate any department, body, or agency as an Examiner of Electronic Evidence to provide expert opinions on electronic form evidence before courts or authorities.

Description: Section 80-Power of police officer and other officers to enter, search, etc.
Content: A police officer (not below Inspector rank) or an authorized government officer may enter, search, and arrest without a warrant in a public place if a person is suspected of committing an offense under the IT Act.
The provisions of this Act shall prevail over any other law that is inconsistent with it, except for rights under the Copyright Act and the Patents Act.

Description: Section 81A-Application of the Act to electronic cheque and truncated cheque
Content: The Act applies to electronic and truncated cheques, with necessary modifications and amendments by the Central Government in consultation with the RBI.
Whoever abets an offense under this Act shall be punished as if they had committed the offense themselves.
Punishment: Same as the punishment prescribed for the committed offense.

Description: Section 84C-Punishment for attempt to commit offences
Content: Whoever attempts to commit an offense under this Act shall be punished with up to half the maximum imprisonment term prescribed for that offense, or with a fine, or both.
Punishment: Imprisonment up to half of the maximum term for the offense, or fine, or both.

Content: If a company commits an offense under this Act, every responsible person shall be held liable unless they prove lack of knowledge or due diligence in preventing the offense. Directors, managers, and other officers may also be held liable if the offense occurred due to their negligence or connivance.

Description: Section 87-Power of Central Government to make rules
Content: The Central Government may make rules to implement the provisions of this Act, including rules for electronic signatures, security practices, encryption, and data protection.

The Central Government shall constitute the Cyber Regulations Advisory Committee, which consists of a Chairperson and official and non-official members. The committee advises the Central Government on rules and regulations and assists the Controller in framing regulations under this Act.

Description: Section 89-Power of Controller to Make Regulations
Content: The Controller, after consultation with the Cyber Regulations Advisory Committee and with prior approval from the Central Government, may make regulations to carry out the provisions of this Act. These regulations may cover database maintenance, recognition of foreign certifying authorities, licensing terms, standards, disclosure requirements, and private key compromise communication.

Description: Section 90-Power of State Government to Make Rules
Content: The State Government may make rules to implement the provisions of this Act, including regulations on electronic filing, issue, grant, receipt, and payment. These rules shall be presented before the State Legislature for approval.
The Controller may, in writing, authorise the Deputy Controller, Assistant Controller or any officer to exercise any of the powers of the Controller

Description: Section 84- Protection of action taken in good faith
Content: No suit,prosecution,or other legal proceeding shall lie against Central Government, State Government, or any person acting on their behalf for anything done in good faith under this act or rules made there under.

Description: Section 82-controller, deputy controller and assistant controller to be the public servants
Content: As per the section, the controller, deputy controller and assistant controller appointed under the IT act shall be deemed to be public servants within the meaning of section 21 all Indian penal code

The central government may issue directions to the controller or any other authority under this act, as it deems necessary in the interest of the sovereignty, integrity and security of India, friendly relations with foreign states , public order, or to prevent incitement to the commission of any cognizable offence.

If any difficulty arises in giving effort to the provisions of this act, central government may issue orders to remove such difficulties, provided that no such order shall be made after the expiry of two years from the commencement of IT act, 2000

Description: Section 77-  Compensation, penalties, or confiscation not to interfere with other punishment
Content: The imposition of any penalty, award of compensation or confiscation under this act shall not prevent the imposition of any other punishment under any other law in force. This insures that penalties under the IT act do not override or exempt individuals from facing additional legal consequences.
